segmentAnalyses.segment: The Council of the European Union, often referred to in the treaties and other official documents simply as the Council,[a] and less formally known as the Council of Ministers, is the third of the seven institutions of the European Union (EU) as listed in the Treaty on European Union.[2] It is one of two legislative bodies and together with the European Parliament serves to amend and approve, or veto, the proposals of the European Commission, which holds the right of initiative.[3][4][5]The Council of the European Union and the European Council are the only EU institutions that are explicitly intergovernmental, that is, forums whose attendees express and represent the position of their Member State's executive, be they ambassadors, ministers or heads of state/government.The Council meets in 10 different configurations of 27 national ministers (one per state). The precise membership of these configurations varies according to the topic under consideration; for example, when discussing agricultural policy the council is formed by the 27 national ministers whose portfolio includes this policy area (with the related European commissioners contributing but not voting).
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council of the European Union, also known informally as the Council of Ministers, is the third of the seven EU institutions and functions as one of the two legislative bodies, responsible for amending, approving, or vetoing proposals from the European Commission. It is unique, alongside the European Council, for being explicitly intergovernmental, meaning attendees represent their Member State's executive position. The Council operates in 10 different configurations, each consisting of 27 national ministers whose specific portfolio aligns with the topic under discussion.
standaloneFacts: The Council of the European Union is the third of the seven institutions of the European Union (EU).
The Council of the European Union is less formally known as the Council of Ministers.
The Council of the European Union is one of two legislative bodies of the EU.
The Council of the European Union and the European Council are the only EU institutions that are explicitly intergovernmental.
The European Commission holds the right of initiative for legislative proposals in the EU.
The Council of the European Union meets in 10 different configurations.
Each configuration of the Council of the European Union consists of 27 national ministers (one per state).

segmentAnalyses.segment: CompositionThe presidency of the Council rotates every six months among the governments of EU member states, with the relevant ministers of the respective country holding the Presidency at any given time ensuring the smooth running of the meetings and setting the daily agenda.[6] The continuity between presidencies is provided by an arrangement under which three successive presidencies, known as Presidency trios, share common political programmes. The Foreign Affairs Council (national foreign ministers) is however chaired by the Union's High Representative.[7]Its decisions are made by qualified majority voting in most areas, unanimity in others, or just simple majority for procedural issues. Usually where it operates unanimously, it only needs to consult the Parliament. However, in most areas the ordinary legislative procedure applies meaning both Council and Parliament share legislative and budgetary powers equally, meaning both have to agree for a proposal to pass. In a few limited areas the Council may initiate new EU law itself.[6]The General Secretariat of the Council of the European Union, also known as Council Secretariat, assists the Council of the European Union, the presidency of the Council of the European Union, the European Council and the president of the European Council.[8] The Secretariat is headed by the secretary-general of the Council of the European Union.[9] The Secretariat is divided into eleven directorates-general, each administered by a director-general.[10]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The presidency of the Council rotates among EU member states every six months, with continuity ensured by Presidency trios sharing common political programs, although the Foreign Affairs Council is chaired by the Union's High Representative. Decision-making primarily uses qualified majority voting, but the Ordinary Legislative Procedure ensures the Council shares equal legislative and budgetary powers with the European Parliament in most areas. Administrative support for the Council, its presidency, and the European Council is provided by the General Secretariat, which is headed by the Secretary-General and structured into eleven directorates-general.
standaloneFacts: The presidency of the Council rotates every six months among the governments of EU member states.
Continuity between Council presidencies is provided by Presidency trios sharing common political programmes.
The Foreign Affairs Council is chaired by the Union's High Representative.
The Council of the European Union makes decisions by qualified majority voting in most areas.
The Council of the European Union requires unanimity for decisions in certain areas.
For procedural issues, the Council of the European Union uses a simple majority for decision making.
In most areas, the Ordinary Legislative Procedure applies, meaning the Council and Parliament share legislative and budgetary powers equally.
The General Secretariat of the Council of the European Union assists the Council, the Council presidency, the European Council, and the president of the European Council.
The General Secretariat of the Council of the European Union is headed by the secretary-general.
The General Secretariat of the Council is divided into eleven directorates-general.

segmentAnalyses.segment: HistoryFurther information: History of the European UnionThe Council first appeared in the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) as the "Special Council of Ministers", set up to counterbalance the High Authority (the supranational executive, now the commission). The original Council had limited powers: issues relating only to coal and steel were in the Authority's domain, and the council's consent was only required on decisions outside coal and steel. As a whole, the Council only scrutinised the High Authority (the executive). In 1957, the Treaties of Rome established two new communities, and with them two new Councils: the Council of the European Atomic Energy Community (EAEC) and the Council of the European Economic Community (EEC). However, due to objections over the supranational power of the Authority, their Councils had more powers; the new executive bodies were known as "Commissions".[11]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council originated in the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) as the "Special Council of Ministers," initially designed to counterbalance the High Authority (the executive) but possessing limited powers, requiring consent only for non-coal and steel issues. Following the 1957 Treaties of Rome, two new Councils were established for the European Atomic Energy Community (EAEC) and the European Economic Community (EEC). These newer Councils were granted greater powers due to objections regarding the supranational authority of the executive bodies, which were then known as "Commissions."
standaloneFacts: The Council first appeared in the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) as the "Special Council of Ministers."
The "Special Council of Ministers" was set up to counterbalance the High Authority, which was the supranational executive of the ECSC.
The Treaties of Rome (1957) established the Council of the European Atomic Energy Community (EAEC) and the Council of the European Economic Community (EEC).
The Councils established by the Treaties of Rome had more powers than the original ECSC Council.

segmentAnalyses.segment: In 1965, the council was hit by the "empty chair crisis". Due to disagreements between French president Charles de Gaulle and the commission's agriculture proposals, among other things, France boycotted all meetings of the council. This halted the council's work until the impasse was resolved the following year by the Luxembourg compromise. Although initiated by a gamble of the President of the commission, Walter Hallstein, who later on lost the Presidency, the crisis exposed flaws in the council's workings.[12]Under the Merger Treaty of 1967, the ECSC's Special Council of Ministers and the Council of the EAEC (together with their other independent institutions) were merged into the Council of the European Communities, which would act as a single Council for all three institutions.[13] In 1993, the Council adopted the name 'Council of the European Union', following the establishment of the European Union by the Maastricht Treaty. That treaty strengthened the council, with the addition of more intergovernmental elements in the three pillars system. However, at the same time the Parliament and Commission had been strengthened inside the Community pillar, curtailing the ability of the council to act independently.[11]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council faced a major institutional challenge in 1965 with the "empty chair crisis," where France boycotted meetings due to disagreements, an impasse resolved by the Luxembourg compromise the following year. Institutionally, the Council evolved significantly, merging the ECSC and EAEC councils in 1967 under the Merger Treaty to form the Council of the European Communities. In 1993, following the Maastricht Treaty, it adopted the name 'Council of the European Union,' a treaty that simultaneously strengthened the Council through intergovernmental elements and curtailed its independence by enhancing the powers of the Parliament and Commission.
standaloneFacts: The council was affected by the "empty chair crisis" starting in 1965.
The "empty chair crisis" was caused partly by disagreements between French president Charles de Gaulle and the commission's agriculture proposals.
The "empty chair crisis" was resolved by the Luxembourg compromise in 1966.
Under the Merger Treaty of 1967, the ECSC's Special Council of Ministers and the Council of the EAEC were merged into the Council of the European Communities.
The Council adopted the name 'Council of the European Union' in 1993.
The adoption of the name 'Council of the European Union' followed the establishment of the European Union by the Maastricht Treaty.
The Maastricht Treaty strengthened the council with the addition of more intergovernmental elements in the three pillars system.

segmentAnalyses.segment: The Treaty of Lisbon abolished the pillar system and gave further powers to Parliament. It also merged the council's High Representative with the Commission's foreign policy head, with this new figure chairing the foreign affairs Council rather than the rotating presidency. The European Council was declared a separate institution from the council, also chaired by a permanent president, and the different Council configurations were mentioned in the treaties for the first time.[7]The development of the council has been characterised by the rise in power of the Parliament, with which the council has had to share its legislative powers. The Parliament has often provided opposition to the council's wishes. This has in some cases led to clashes between both bodies with the council's system of intergovernmentalism contradicting the developing parliamentary system and supranational principles.[14]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Treaty of Lisbon introduced major changes by abolishing the pillar system, granting further powers to the Parliament, and formally separating the European Council as a distinct institution. The Treaty also merged the council's High Representative with the Commission's foreign policy head, creating a new figure to chair the foreign affairs Council. Overall, the Council's development has been marked by sharing legislative powers with the increasingly powerful Parliament, which often results in clashes between the Council's intergovernmentalism and developing supranational principles.
standaloneFacts: The Treaty of Lisbon abolished the pillar system.
The Treaty of Lisbon gave further powers to the Parliament.
The Treaty of Lisbon merged the council's High Representative with the Commission's foreign policy head.
The merged foreign policy figure chairs the foreign affairs Council instead of the rotating presidency.
The Treaty of Lisbon declared the European Council a separate institution from the council.
The European Council is chaired by a permanent president.
The Treaty of Lisbon marked the first time the different Council configurations were mentioned in the treaties.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Powers and functionsThe primary purpose of the council is to act as one of two vetoing bodies of the EU's legislative branch, the other being the European Parliament. Together they serve to amend, approve or disapprove the proposals of the European Commission, which has the sole power to propose laws.[3][5] Jointly with the Parliament, the Council holds the budgetary power of the Union and has greater control than the Parliament over the more intergovernmental areas of the EU, such as foreign policy and macroeconomic co-ordination. Finally, before the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, it formally held the executive power of the EU which it conferred upon the European Commission.[15][16] It is considered by some to be equivalent to an upper house of the EU legislature, although it is not described as such in the treaties.[17][18][19] The Council represents the executive governments of the EU's member states[2][15] and is based in the Europa building in Brussels.[20]The council also has an important role in the formation of the European Commission. The Council sitting in the General Affairs Council configuration, in agreement with the President-elect of the Commissission, adopts a list of candidates for the Commission proposed by the member states.[21]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council acts as a primary component of the EU's legislative branch, serving as one of two vetoing bodies alongside the European Parliament, and works to amend or approve proposals from the European Commission. It shares the Union's budgetary power with the Parliament and retains greater authority over intergovernmental areas like foreign policy and macroeconomic co-ordination. Representing the executive governments of member states, the Council also plays an essential role in the formation of the European Commission by adopting the list of candidate commissioners.
standaloneFacts: The Council is one of two vetoing bodies in the EU's legislative branch, the other being the European Parliament.
The European Commission has the sole power to propose EU laws.
The Council, jointly with the European Parliament, holds the budgetary power of the European Union.
The Council has greater control than the Parliament over intergovernmental areas of the EU, such as foreign policy and macroeconomic co-ordination.
Before the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the Council formally held the executive power of the EU, which it conferred upon the European Commission.
The Council represents the executive governments of the EU's member states.
The Council is based in the Europa building in Brussels.
The Council, sitting in the General Affairs Council configuration, adopts a list of candidates for the European Commission in agreement with the President-elect of the Commission.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Legislative procedureMain article: European Union legislative procedureSimplified illustration of the voting rules that apply within the ordinary legislative procedure. The actual procedure involves various stages of consultations aimed at achieving compromise between the positions of the two legislative chambers.The EU's legislative authority is divided between the council, the Parliament and the commission. As the relationships and powers of these institutions have developed, various legislative procedures have been created for adopting laws.[15] In early times, the avis facultatif maxim was: "The Commission proposes, and the Council disposes";[22] but now the vast majority of laws are subject to the ordinary legislative procedure, which works on the principle that consent from both the Council and Parliament are required before a law may be adopted.[23]Under this procedure, the Commission presents a proposal to Parliament and the council. Following its first reading the Parliament may propose amendments. If the Council accepts these amendments then the legislation is approved. If it does not then it adopts a "common position" and submits that new version to the Parliament. At its second reading, if the Parliament approves the text or does not act, the text is adopted, otherwise the Parliament may propose further amendments to the council's proposal.
segmentAnalyses.summary: The EU's legislative authority is divided among the Council, the Parliament, and the Commission, with the vast majority of laws now subject to the ordinary legislative procedure (OLP). The OLP requires consent from both the Council and the Parliament and begins with a proposal from the Commission. The process involves multiple readings, allowing the Parliament to propose amendments and the Council to adopt a "common position" if amendments are not initially accepted.
standaloneFacts: The EU's legislative authority is divided between the Council, the Parliament, and the Commission.
The vast majority of EU laws are subject to the ordinary legislative procedure.
The ordinary legislative procedure requires consent from both the Council and the Parliament before a law may be adopted.
Under the ordinary legislative procedure, the Commission presents a proposal to Parliament and the Council.
Historically, the maxim describing early EU legislative procedure was: "The Commission proposes, and the Council disposes."

segmentAnalyses.segment: It may be rejected out right by an absolute majority of MEPs. If the Council still does not approve the Parliament's position, then the text is taken to a "Conciliation Committee" composed of the Council members plus an equal number of MEPs. If a Committee manages to adopt a joint text, it then has to be approved in a third reading by both the Council and Parliament or the proposal is abandoned.[24]The few other areas that operate the special legislative procedures are justice & home affairs, budget and taxation and certain aspects of other policy areas: such as the fiscal aspects of environmental policy. In these areas, the council or Parliament decide law alone.[25][26] The procedure used also depends upon which type of institutional act is being used. The strongest act is a regulation, an act or law which is directly applicable in its entirety. Then there are directives which bind members to certain goals which they must achieve, but they do this through their own laws and hence have room to manoeuvre in deciding upon them. A decision is an instrument which is focused at a particular person or group and is directly applicable. Institutions may also issue recommendations and opinions which are merely non-binding declarations.[27]The Council votes in one of three ways; unanimity, simple majority, or qualified majority. In most cases, the Council votes on issues by qualified majority voting, meaning that there must be a minimum of 55% of member states agreeing (at least 15) who together represent at least 65% of the EU population.[28] A 'blocki
segmentAnalyses.summary: The text details the final steps of the Ordinary Legislative Procedure, involving a potential Conciliation Committee and third reading if consensus is not reached between the Council and Parliament. It defines the hierarchy of EU legal acts, including directly applicable Regulations and non-binding Recommendations, and notes that special legislative procedures apply to areas like justice and budget. Furthermore, it specifies that the Council predominantly votes using Qualified Majority Voting (QMV), which requires agreement from 55% of member states representing 65% of the EU population.
standaloneFacts: If the Council still does not approve the Parliament's position, the legislative text is taken to a "Conciliation Committee."
A Conciliation Committee is composed of Council members plus an equal number of MEPs.
If a joint text is adopted by the Conciliation Committee, it must be approved in a third reading by both the Council and Parliament.
Special legislative procedures apply to areas such as justice & home affairs, budget and taxation, and certain fiscal aspects of environmental policy.
The strongest institutional act is a regulation, which is a law directly applicable in its entirety.
Directives bind member states to certain goals which they must achieve through their own national laws.
A decision is an instrument focused at a particular person or group and is directly applicable.
Institutions may issue recommendations and opinions, which are non-binding declarations.
The Council votes in one of three ways: unanimity, simple majority, or qualified majority.
Qualified Majority Voting (QMV) requires a minimum of 55% of member states agreeing (at least 15) who together represent at least 65% of the EU population.

segmentAnalyses.segment: ng minority' can only be formed by at least 4 member states, even if the objecting states constitute more than 35% of the population.[29]Resolution sCouncil resolutions have no legal effect. Usually the council's intention is to set out future work foreseen in a specific policy area or to invite action by the commission. If a resolution covers a policy area which is not entirely within an area of EU competency, the resolution will be issued as a "resolution of the Council and the representatives of the governments of the member states".[30] Examples are the Council Resolution of 26 September 1989 on the development of subcontracting in the Community[31] and the Council Resolution of 26 November 2001 on consumer credit and indebtedness.[32]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The text defines the requirements for forming a 'blocking minority' during Council votes, specifying that at least four member states must object, even if the objecting population share exceeds 35%. It then clarifies that Council resolutions lack legal effect, serving primarily to set out future policy work or invite Commission action. Furthermore, resolutions covering policy areas not entirely within EU competence are issued under a specific joint title involving the member states' governments.
standaloneFacts: A 'blocking minority' in the EU Council can only be formed by at least 4 member states, even if the objecting states constitute more than 35% of the EU population.
Council resolutions have no legal effect.
The usual intention of a Council resolution is to set out future work foreseen in a specific policy area or to invite action by the Commission.
If a resolution covers a policy area not entirely within EU competency, it is issued as a "resolution of the Council and the representatives of the governments of the member states".

segmentAnalyses.segment: Foreign affairsThe legal instruments used by the council for the Common Foreign and Security Policy are different from the legislative acts. Under the CFSP they consist of "common positions", "joint actions", and "common strategies". Common positions relate to defining a European foreign policy towards a particular third-country such as the promotion of human rights and democracy in Myanmar, a region such as the stabilisation efforts in the African Great Lakes, or a certain issue such as support for the International Criminal Court. A common position, once agreed, is binding on all EU states who must follow and defend the policy, which is regularly revised. A joint action refers to a co-ordinated action of the states to deploy resources to achieve an objective, for example for mine clearing or to combat the spread of small arms. Common strategies defined an objective and commits the EUs resources to that task for four years.[33]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The legal instruments used by the Council for the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) are distinct from standard legislative acts and include "common positions," "joint actions," and "common strategies." Common positions define foreign policy towards specific regions, countries, or issues (e.g., human rights in Myanmar) and are binding on all EU states. Joint actions involve coordinated resource deployment for specific objectives, while common strategies define an objective and commit EU resources for four years.
standaloneFacts: The legal instruments used by the Council for the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) are different from legislative acts.
The legal instruments used under the CFSP consist of "common positions," "joint actions," and "common strategies."
A common position defines a European foreign policy towards a particular third-country, region, or issue.
A common position, once agreed, is binding on all EU states.
A joint action refers to a co-ordinated action of EU states to deploy resources to achieve an objective, such as mine clearing.
Common strategies define an objective and commit the EU's resources to that task for four years.

segmentAnalyses.segment: The Council must practice unanimity when voting on foreign affairs issues because Common Foreign and Security Policy is a "sensitive" issue (according to EUR-Lex).[34] An exception to this rule exists via Article 31 of the Treaty on European Union, which stipulates circumstances in which qualified majority voting is permissible for the Council in discussing Common Foreign and Security Policy.[34][35][36] Article 31 lays out provisions regarding a passerelle clause as well as the possibilities for Member State abstentions.[35][37] Additionally, Article 31 stipulates derogation for "a decision defining a Union action or position".[35][37] In late 2023 and early 2024, unanimity voting on foreign affairs issues by the council made headlines due to the resistance of Viktor Orbán, Prime Minister of Hungary, to passing European Union aid to Ukraine.[38][39][40] In this recent example, the Council came to a unified conclusion after discussions with the Hungarian leader;[40] previously at the end of 2023, Orbán had left the room during the Council vote on Ukraine-EU accession talks, this ensuring that the Council passed that issue without veto.[39]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council is required to vote with unanimity on sensitive Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) issues, though Article 31 of the Treaty on European Union allows exceptions, stipulating circumstances where qualified majority voting (QMV) is permissible, alongside provisions for abstentions and a passerelle clause. This unanimity requirement drew attention in late 2023 and early 2024 due to the resistance of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán to passing European Union aid to Ukraine.
standaloneFacts: The Council must practice unanimity when voting on foreign affairs issues because Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) is considered a "sensitive" issue.
An exception to the unanimity rule for foreign affairs exists via Article 31 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU).
Article 31 of the TEU stipulates circumstances in which qualified majority voting is permissible for the Council in discussing Common Foreign and Security Policy.
Article 31 includes provisions regarding a passerelle clause, Member State abstentions, and derogation for "a decision defining a Union action or position."
In late 2023 and early 2024, unanimity voting on foreign affairs issues made headlines due to the resistance of Viktor Orbán, Prime Minister of Hungary, to passing European Union aid to Ukraine.
Viktor Orbán left the room during a Council vote on Ukraine-EU accession talks at the end of 2023, ensuring that the Council passed that issue without a veto.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Budgetary authorityThe legislative branch officially holds the Union's budgetary authority. The EU's budget (which is around 155 billion euro)[41] is subject to a form of the ordinary legislative procedure with a single reading giving Parliament power over the entire budget (prior to 2009, its influence was limited to certain areas) on an equal footing with the council. If there is a disagreement between them, it is taken to a conciliation committee as it is for legislative proposals. But if the joint conciliation text is not approved, the Parliament may adopt the budget definitively.[25] In addition to the budget, the Council coordinates the economic policy of members.[6]OrganisationThe council's rules of procedure contain the provisions necessary for its organisation and functioning.[42]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The legislative branch officially holds the European Union's budgetary authority over the approximately 155 billion euro EU budget, using a modified ordinary legislative procedure. Since 2009, the Parliament shares equal footing with the Council over the entire budget; while disagreements are taken to a conciliation committee, the Parliament ultimately retains the power to definitively adopt the budget if conciliation fails. Additionally, the Council coordinates the economic policy of member states, and its organization is governed by its rules of procedure.
standaloneFacts: The legislative branch officially holds the European Union's budgetary authority.
The EU's budget is around 155 billion euro.
The EU budget is subject to a form of the ordinary legislative procedure with a single reading.
Since 2009, the European Parliament has power over the entire EU budget on an equal footing with the Council.
If the joint conciliation text regarding the budget is not approved, the European Parliament may adopt the budget definitively.
The Council coordinates the economic policy of member states.
The council's rules of procedure contain the provisions necessary for its organisation and functioning.

segmentAnalyses.segment: PresidencyMain article: Presidency of the Council of the European UnionThe Presidency of the council is not a single post, but is held by a member state's government. Every six months the presidency rotates among the states, in an order predefined by the council's members, allowing each state to preside over the body. From 2007, every three member states co-operate for their combined eighteen months on a common agenda, although only one formally holds the presidency for the normal six-month period. For example, the President for the second half of 2007, Portugal, was the second in a trio of states alongside Germany and Slovenia with whom Portugal had been co-operating. The Council meets in various configurations (as outlined below) so its membership changes depending upon the issue. The person chairing the council will always be the member from the state holding the Presidency. A delegate from the following Presidency also assists the presiding member and may take over work if requested.[43][44] The exception however is the foreign affairs council, which has been chaired by the High Representative since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.[7]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Presidency of the Council of the European Union is not a single post but rotates among member states' governments every six months in a predefined order. Since 2007, groups of three member states cooperate on a common 18-month agenda, although only one formally holds the six-month presidency at a time. The chair of any Council configuration is typically the member from the presiding state, with the exception of the Foreign Affairs Council, which has been chaired by the High Representative since the Lisbon Treaty.
standaloneFacts: The Presidency of the Council of the European Union rotates among member states every six months.
The Presidency of the Council of the European Union is held by a member state's government.
Since 2007, three member states typically co-operate for eighteen months on a common agenda for the Council Presidency.
The person chairing the Council is always the member from the state holding the Presidency.
The Foreign Affairs Council is an exception to the chairing rule, having been chaired by the High Representative since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.

segmentAnalyses.segment: The role of the Presidency is administrative and political. On the administrative side it is responsible for procedures and organising the work of the council during its term. This includes summoning the council for meetings along with directing the work of COREPER and other committees and working parties. The political element is the role of successfully dealing with issues and mediating in the council. In particular this includes setting the agenda of the council, hence giving the Presidency substantial influence in the work of the council during its term. The Presidency also plays a major role in representing the Council within the EU and representing the EU internationally, for example at the United Nations.[44][45][46]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The role of the Council Presidency is dual, encompassing both administrative and political responsibilities. Administratively, it is responsible for organizing the council's work, summoning meetings, and directing COREPER and other working groups. Politically, the Presidency mediates issues, sets the council's agenda (thereby gaining substantial influence), and plays a major representational role for the Council within the EU and for the EU internationally (e.g., at the UN).
standaloneFacts: The role of the Council Presidency is administrative and political.
The administrative responsibilities of the Presidency include organizing the council's work, summoning meetings, and directing the work of COREPER and other working parties.
The political element of the Presidency is the role of successfully dealing with issues and mediating in the council.
By setting the agenda of the council, the Presidency gains substantial influence in the work of the council during its term.
The Presidency plays a major role in representing the Council within the EU and representing the EU internationally, for example at the United Nations.

segmentAnalyses.segment: ConfigurationsLegally speaking, the council is a single entity (this means that technically any Council configuration can adopt decisions that fall within the remit of any other Council configuration)[47] but it is in practice divided into several different council configurations (or '(con)formations'). Article 16(6) of the Treaty on European Union provides:The Council shall meet in different configurations, the list of which shall be adopted in accordance with Article 236 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.The General Affairs Council shall ensure consistency in the work of the different Council configurations. It shall prepare and ensure the follow-up to meetings of the European Council, in liaison with the President of the European Council and the Commission.The Foreign Affairs Council shall elaborate the Union's external action on the basis of strategic guidelines laid down by the European Council and ensure that the Union's action is consistent.
segmentAnalyses.summary: While the Council of the European Union is legally a single entity, capable of having any configuration adopt decisions belonging to another, it is practically divided into specialized configurations ('formations'). This structure is mandated by Article 16(6) of the Treaty on European Union. Key among these are the General Affairs Council, which ensures consistency and prepares European Council meetings, and the Foreign Affairs Council, which elaborates and ensures consistency regarding the Union's external action.
standaloneFacts: Legally speaking, the Council of the European Union is a single entity.
The Council is in practice divided into several different council configurations (or 'formations').
Article 16(6) of the Treaty on European Union states that the Council shall meet in different configurations.
The list of Council configurations shall be adopted in accordance with Article 236 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
The General Affairs Council ensures consistency in the work of the different Council configurations.
The General Affairs Council prepares and ensures the follow-up to meetings of the European Council, in liaison with the President of the European Council and the Commission.
The Foreign Affairs Council elaborates the Union's external action based on strategic guidelines laid down by the European Council.
The Foreign Affairs Council ensures that the Union's external action is consistent.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Each council configuration deals with a different functional area, for example agriculture and fisheries. In this formation, the council is composed of ministers from each state government who are responsible for this area: the agriculture and fisheries ministers. The chair of this council is held by the member from the state holding the presidency (see section above). Similarly, the Economic and Financial Affairs Council is composed of national finance ministers, and they are still one per state and the chair is held by the member coming from the presiding country. The Councils meet irregularly throughout the year except for the three major configurations (top three below) which meet once a month. As of 2020, there are ten formations:[48][49]General Affairs (GAC)General affairs co-ordinates the work of the council, prepares for European Council meetings and deals with issues crossing various council formations.Foreign Affairs (FAC)Chaired by the High Representative, rather than the Presidency, it manages the CFSP, CSDP, trade and development co-operation. It sometimes meets in a defence configuration.[50]Since 2017, the Europa building, seen here, has been the seat of the council.Economic and Financial Affairs (Ecofin)Composed of economics and finance ministers of the member states. It includes budgetary and eurozone matters via an informal group composed only of eurozone member ministers.[51]
segmentAnalyses.summary: Council configurations are composed of national ministers specializing in a particular functional area, with the chair typically held by the member from the presiding state. Although most councils meet irregularly, the three major configurations—General Affairs (GAC), Foreign Affairs (FAC), and Economic and Financial Affairs (Ecofin)—meet once a month. As of 2020, there are ten formations, and the FAC is uniquely chaired by the High Representative rather than the Presidency.
standaloneFacts: Each council configuration deals with a different functional area.
The chair of a council configuration is held by the member from the state holding the presidency.
As of 2020, there are ten council formations.
The three major council configurations (GAC, FAC, Ecofin) meet once a month.
The General Affairs Council (GAC) coordinates the work of the council and prepares for European Council meetings.
The Foreign Affairs Council (FAC) is chaired by the High Representative, rather than the Presidency.
The Foreign Affairs Council (FAC) manages the CFSP, CSDP, trade, and development co-operation.
The Economic and Financial Affairs Council (Ecofin) is composed of economics and finance ministers of the member states.
The Europa building has been the seat of the council since 2017.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Agriculture and Fisheries (Agrifish)Composed of the agriculture and fisheries ministers of the member states. It considers matters concerning the Common Agricultural Policy, the Common Fisheries Policy, forestry, organic farming, food and feed safety, seeds, pesticides, and fisheries.[52]Justice and Home Affairs (JHA)This configuration brings together Justice ministers and Interior Ministers of the Member States. Includes civil protection.Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs (EPSCO)Composed of employment, social protection, consumer protection, health and equal opportunities ministers.Competitiveness (COMPET)Created in June 2002 through the merging of three previous configurations (Internal Market, Industry and Research). Depending on the items on the agenda, this formation is composed of ministers responsible for areas such as European affairs, industry, tourism and scientific research. With the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the EU acquired competence in space matters,[53] and space policy has been attributed to the Competitiveness Council.[54]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The analyzed segment outlines the composition and policy responsibilities of four specific Council formations: Agrifish, Justice and Home Affairs (JHA), Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs (EPSCO), and Competitiveness (COMPET). These configurations handle issues ranging from common agricultural and fisheries policies and internal security to social welfare, health, and equal opportunities. The Competitiveness Council, established in 2002 by merging three previous configurations, notably handles industry, research, and space policy following the Lisbon Treaty.
standaloneFacts: The Agriculture and Fisheries (Agrifish) Council is composed of agriculture and fisheries ministers.
The Agrifish Council considers matters concerning the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP).
The Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) configuration brings together Justice ministers and Interior Ministers and includes civil protection.
The Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs (EPSCO) Council is composed of ministers covering employment, social protection, consumer protection, health, and equal opportunities.
The Competitiveness (COMPET) Council was created in June 2002 by merging the Internal Market, Industry, and Research configurations.
Space policy has been attributed to the Competitiveness Council since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Transport, Telecommunications and Energy (TTE)Created in June 2002, through the merging of three policies under one configuration, and with a composition varying according to the specific items on its agenda. This formation meets approximately once every two months.Environment (ENVI)Composed of environment ministers, who meet about four times a year.Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS)Composed of education, culture, youth, communications and sport ministers, who meet around three or four times a year.[55] Includes audiovisual issues.Complementing these, the Political and Security Committee (PSC) brings together ambassadors to monitor international situations and define policies within the CSDP, particularly in crises.[49] The European Council is similar to a configuration of the council and operates in a similar way, but is composed of the national leaders (heads of government or state) and h
segmentAnalyses.summary: This segment describes several configurations of the Council of the European Union, including the Transport, Telecommunications and Energy (TTE) Council, the Environment (ENVI) Council, and the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council, noting their specific ministerial compositions and meeting frequencies. It also introduces the Political and Security Committee (PSC), which monitors international situations and defines CSDP policies. Finally, it notes that the European Council is similar to a configuration of the council but is composed of national leaders (heads of government or state) and has its own President.
standaloneFacts: The Transport, Telecommunications and Energy (TTE) Council was created in June 2002.
The TTE Council meets approximately once every two months.
The Environment (ENVI) Council meets about four times a year.
The Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council meets around three or four times a year.
The EYCS Council includes audiovisual issues.
The Political and Security Committee (PSC) brings together ambassadors to monitor international situations and define policies within the CSDP.
The European Council is composed of national leaders (heads of government or state).

segmentAnalyses.segment: as its own President,[56] since 2019, Charles Michel. The body's purpose is to define the general "impetus" of the Union.[57] The European Council deals with the major issues such as the appointment of the President of the European Commission who takes part in the body's meetings.[58]Ecofin's Eurozone component, the Euro group, is also a formal group with its own President.[51] Its European Council counterpart is the Euro summit formalized in 2011[59] and the TSCG.Following the entry into force of a framework agreement between the EU and ESA there is a Space Council configuration—a joint and concomitant meeting of the EU Council and of the ESA Council at ministerial level dealing with the implementation of the ESP adopted by both organisations.[60][61]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The European Council, defining the general direction of the Union, is headed by its President, Charles Michel, since 2019, and addresses major issues like appointing the European Commission President. The text also notes related bodies, including the Euro group (Ecofin's Eurozone component) and the formalized Euro summit (2011). Furthermore, a Space Council configuration exists as a joint ministerial meeting between the EU Council and the ESA Council for implementing the ESP.
standaloneFacts: Charles Michel has been the President of the European Council since 2019.
The European Council's purpose is to define the general "impetus" of the Union.
The European Council deals with major issues, such as the appointment of the President of the European Commission.
The Euro group is the Eurozone component of Ecofin and is a formal group with its own President.
The Euro summit was formalized in 2011 and serves as the European Council counterpart to the Euro group.
The Space Council configuration is a joint ministerial meeting of the EU Council and the ESA Council.

segmentAnalyses.segment: Administration The General Secretariat of the Council provides the continuous infrastructure of the council, carrying out preparation for meetings, draft reports, translation, records, documents, agendas and assisting the presidency.[62] The Secretary General of the Council is head of the Secretariat.[9] The Secretariat is divided into eleven directorates-general, each administered by a director-general.[10]The Committee of Permanent Representatives (COREPER) is a body composed of representatives from the states (ambassadors, civil servants etc.) who meet each week to prepare the work and tasks of the council. It monitors and co-ordinates work and deals with the Parliament on co-decision legislation.[63] It is divided into two groups of the representatives (Coreper II) and their deputies (Coreper I). Agriculture is dealt with separately by the Special Committee on Agriculture (SCA). The numerous working parties submit their reports to the Council through Coreper or SCA.[49]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Council's administration relies on the General Secretariat, which provides continuous infrastructure functions such as preparing meetings, drafting reports, and translation, and is led by the Secretary General. Operational preparation and coordination are managed by the Committee of Permanent Representatives (COREPER), a body of state representatives (ambassadors and civil servants) that meets weekly to prepare tasks and deal with co-decision legislation with the Parliament. Agricultural issues are handled separately by the Special Committee on Agriculture (SCA).
standaloneFacts: The General Secretariat of the Council provides the continuous infrastructure of the council, handling preparation for meetings, draft reports, translation, records, documents, and agendas.
The Secretary General of the Council is the head of the Secretariat.
The Secretariat is divided into eleven directorates-general, each administered by a director-general.
The Committee of Permanent Representatives (COREPER) is composed of representatives from the states (ambassadors and civil servants).
COREPER meets each week to prepare the work and tasks of the council.
COREPER monitors and co-ordinates work and deals with the Parliament on co-decision legislation.
COREPER is divided into two groups: Coreper II (representatives) and Coreper I (deputies).
Agriculture is dealt with separately by the Special Committee on Agriculture (SCA).

segmentAnalyses.segment: Governments represented in the Council Further information: Voting in the Council of the European Union The Treaty of Lisbon mandated a change in voting system from 1 November 2014 for most cases to double majority Qualified Majority Voting, replacing the voting weights system. Decisions made by the council have to be taken by 55% of member states representing at least 65% of the EU's population.[7]Almost all members of the council are members of a political party at national level, and most of these are members of a European-level political party. However the council is composed to represent the Member States rather than political parties[6] and the nature of coalition governments in a number of states means that party breakdown at different configuration of the Council vary depending on which domestic party was assigned the portfolio. However, the broad ideological alignment of the government in each state does influence the nature of the law the Council produces and the extent to which the link between domestic parties puts pressure on the members in the European Parliament to vote a certain way.
segmentAnalyses.summary: The Treaty of Lisbon mandated the shift to double majority Qualified Majority Voting (QMV) in the Council, effective November 1, 2014, requiring 55% of member states representing 65% of the EU population for decisions. Although council members typically belong to national and European political parties, the Council's primary role is to represent Member States; nevertheless, the ideological alignment of national governments significantly influences the legislation the Council produces.
standaloneFacts: The Treaty of Lisbon mandated a change in the Council's voting system to double majority Qualified Majority Voting (QMV).
The double majority QMV system replaced the previous voting weights system and took effect on November 1, 2014, for most cases.
Council decisions under QMV must be taken by 55% of member states representing at least 65% of the EU's population.
The Council is structured to represent Member States rather than political parties.
Almost all members of the Council are members of a political party at the national level, and most are also members of a European-level political party.

segmentAnalyses.segment: State	Governing parties	EU party	EU group	Population	Cabinet Germany	Christian Democratic Union of Germany		EPP		EPP	84,311,244	Merz Social Democratic Party of Germany		PES		S&D Christian Social Union in Bavaria		EPP		EPP France	Renaissance		None		RE	68,070,697	Lecornu Democratic Movement		EDP		RE Horizons		None		RE Union of Democrats and Independents		ALDE		RE Italy	Brothers of Italy		ECR		ECR	59,691,110	Meloni League for Salvini Premier		P.eu		PfE Forza Italia		EPP		EPP Us Moderates		EPP		None Spain	Spanish Socialist Workers' Party		PES		S&D	48,063,694	Sánchez III Socialists' Party of Catalonia		None		S&D Unite Movement		None		Left United Left		PEL		None Catalonia in Common		EGP		G/EFA More Madrid		None		None
segmentAnalyses.summary: The segment details the governing coalitions, populations, and cabinet designations for four major EU Member States: Germany, France, Italy, and Spain. It specifies the national governing parties in each country, along with their associated European political parties and corresponding EU parliamentary groups, illustrating the complexity of political alignments across the bloc.
standaloneFacts: Germany has a population of 84,311,244 and its cabinet is named Merz.
The German governing coalition includes the Christian Democratic Union of Germany (EPP), the Social Democratic Party of Germany (PES), and the Christian Social Union in Bavaria (EPP).
France has a population of 68,070,697 and its cabinet is named Lecornu.
The Italian cabinet is named Meloni and the country has a population of 59,691,110.
Governing parties in Italy include Brothers of Italy (ECR), League for Salvini Premier, Forza Italia (EPP), and Us Moderates (EPP).
Spain, with a population of 48,063,694, has a cabinet designated Sánchez III.
The Spanish governing coalition includes the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PES/S&D) and multiple smaller parties such as Unite Movement and United Left (PEL).

segmentAnalyses.segment: Poland	Civic Coalition		EPP		EPP	37,723,532	Tusk III Polish People's Party		EPP		EPP New Left		PES		S&D Szymon Hołownia's Poland 2050		None		RE Romania	National Liberal Party		EPP		EPP	19,051,562	Bolojan Social Democratic Party		PES		S&D Save Romania Union		ALDE		RE Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania		EPP		EPP Renewing Romania's European Project		None		None Netherlands	People's Party for Freedom and Democracy		ALDE		RE	17,956,453	Schoof Farmer–Citizen Movement		None		EPP Belgium	New Flemish Alliance		EFA		ECR	11,754,004	De Wever Reformist Movement		ALDE		RE Les Engagés		EDP		RE Vooruit		PES		S&D Christian Democratic and Flemish		EPP		EPP Czech Republic	Civic Democratic Party		ECR		ECR	10,833,385	Fiala Mayors and Independents		None		EPP KDU-ČSL		EPP		EPP TOP 09		EPP		EPP Portugal	Social Democratic Party		EPP		EPP	10,749,635	Montenegro II CDS – People's Party		EPP		EPP Sweden	Moderate Party		EPP		EPP	10,541,000	Kristersson Christian Democrats		EPP		EPP Liberals		ALDE		RE Greece	New Democracy		EPP		EPP	10,415,585	Mitsotakis II
segmentAnalyses.summary: This segment provides tabular data detailing the governing parties, their EU party and group affiliations, population, and cabinet heads for eight EU member states: Poland, Romania, Netherlands, Belgium, Czech Republic, Portugal, Sweden, and Greece. The data highlights the diverse coalition structures and the prevalence of affiliations with major European political groups such as the EPP, PES, and ALDE/RE across these countries.
standaloneFacts: Poland's governing coalition (Tusk III) includes parties affiliated with EPP, PES, and RE, representing a population of 37,723,532.
Romania's government (Bolojan) includes five parties, with affiliations across EPP, PES, ALDE, and RE, serving a population of 19,051,562.
The Netherlands' Schoof cabinet includes the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (ALDE/RE) and the Farmer–Citizen Movement (None/EPP), governing 17,956,453 people.
Belgium's De Wever cabinet (population 11,754,004) includes parties affiliated with EFA/ECR, ALDE/RE, PES/S&D, and EPP/EPP.
The Czech Republic's Fiala cabinet (population 10,833,385) is composed of parties primarily affiliated with ECR and EPP.
Portugal's Montenegro II cabinet, governing 10,749,635 people, consists of the Social Democratic Party and CDS – People's Party, both affiliated with the EPP.
Sweden's Kristersson cabinet includes the Moderate Party (EPP/EPP), Christian Democrats (EPP/EPP), and Liberals (ALDE/RE), governing 10,541,000 people.
Greece (population 10,415,585) is governed by the Mitsotakis II cabinet, led by the New Democracy party (EPP/EPP).

segmentAnalyses.summary: This segment provides a detailed list of political affiliations and population figures for ten European Union member states, ranging from Hungary (9.6 million) down to Slovenia (2.1 million). Key political parties across these nations are categorized by their national and European Parliament group affiliations, including prominent groups like EPP, S&D, RE, ECR, and non-aligned groups like PfE and NI.
standaloneFacts: The population of Hungary is 9,599,744.
The Fidesz – Hungarian Civic Alliance is affiliated with PfE in the European Union.
The Austrian People's Party is affiliated with the EPP both nationally and at the EU level.
The population of Austria is 9,087,000.
Bulgaria's population is 6,498,567.
Denmark's Social Democrats are affiliated with PES nationally and S&D in the EU.
Direction – Social Democracy in Slovakia is classified as Non-Inscrits (NI) at the EU level.
The population of Ireland is 5,194,336.
The Croatian Democratic Union is affiliated with the EPP.
The population of Slovenia is 2,116,972.

segmentAnalyses.summary: This segment provides political data, including major parties, European affiliations, and population figures, for five smaller EU member states: Latvia, Estonia, Cyprus, Luxembourg, and Malta. Population figures range from 1,883,008 in Latvia down to 542,051 in Malta. The segment concludes with a reference to the location of EU institutions, such as the Europa building and the Justus Lipsius building.
standaloneFacts: Latvia has a population of 1,883,008.
The political party Unity in Latvia is affiliated with the EPP.
Estonia has a population of 1,365,884.
The Estonian Reform Party is affiliated with ALDE and RE.
Cyprus has a population of 920,701.
Luxembourg has a population of 658,278.
Malta has a population of 542,051.
The Labour Party in Malta is affiliated with PES and S&D.

segmentAnalyses.segment: By a decision of the European Council at Edinburgh in December 1992, the council has its seat in Brussels but in April, June, and October, it holds its meetings in Luxembourg City.[64] Between 1952 and 1967, the ECSC Council held its Luxembourg City meetings in the Cercle Municipal on Place d'Armes. Its secretariat moved on numerous occasions but between 1955 and 1967 it was housed in the Verlorenkost district of the city. In 1957, with the creation of two new Communities with their own Councils, discretion on location was given to the current Presidency. In practice this was to be in the Château of Val-Duchesse until the autumn of 1958, at which point it moved to 2 Rue Ravensteinstraat in Brussels.[65]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The European Council decided at Edinburgh in December 1992 that the Council's seat is in Brussels, though meetings are still held in Luxembourg City during April, June, and October. Historically, the ECSC Council met in Luxembourg City at the Cercle Municipal from 1952 to 1967, with its secretariat housed in the Verlorenkost district of the city during part of that period. Following institutional changes in 1957, the Council location eventually moved from the Château of Val-Duchesse to 2 Rue Ravensteinstraat in Brussels by the autumn of 1958.
standaloneFacts: By a decision of the European Council at Edinburgh in December 1992, the council's seat was established in Brussels.
The Council holds its meetings in Luxembourg City during April, June, and October.
Between 1952 and 1967, the ECSC Council held its Luxembourg City meetings in the Cercle Municipal on Place d'Armes.
The ECSC Council secretariat was housed in the Verlorenkost district of Luxembourg City between 1955 and 1967.
The Council location was temporarily at the Château of Val-Duchesse until the autumn of 1958.
In the autumn of 1958, the Council location moved to 2 Rue Ravensteinstraat in Brussels.

segmentAnalyses.segment: The 1965 agreement (finalised by the Edinburgh agreement and annexed to the treaties) on the location of the newly merged institutions, the council was to be in Brussels but would meet in Luxembourg City during April, June, and October. The ECSC secretariat moved from Luxembourg City to the merged body Council secretariat in the Ravenstein building of Brussels. In 1971 the council and its secretariat moved into the Charlemagne building, next to the commission's Berlaymont, but the Council rapidly ran out of space and administrative branch of the Secretariat moved to a building at 76 Rue Joseph II/Jozef II-straat and during the 1980s the language divisions moved out into the Nerviens, Frère Orban, and Guimard buildings.[65]In 1995, the Council moved into the Justus Lipsius building, across the road from Charlemagne.[clarification needed] However, its staff was still increasing, so it continued to rent the Frère Orban building to house the Finnish and Swedish language divisions. Staff continued to increase and the Council rented, in addition to owning Justus Lipsius, the Kortenberg, Froissart, Espace Rolin, and Woluwe Heights buildings. Since acquiring the Lex building in 2008, the three aforementioned buildings are no longer in use by the Council services.[citation needed]
segmentAnalyses.summary: The location history of the Council is characterized by frequent moves driven by institutional mergers and rapid staff growth, beginning with the 1965 agreement establishing Brussels as the seat and mandating meetings in Luxembourg City during April, June, and October. After initial moves to the Ravenstein and Charlemagne buildings, the Council relocated to the Justus Lipsius building in 1995. Due to continued expansion, the Council rented numerous external buildings until the acquisition of the Lex building in 2008 allowed for consolidation of services.
standaloneFacts: The 1965 agreement stipulated that the Council would be based in Brussels but meet in Luxembourg City during April, June, and October.
The ECSC secretariat moved from Luxembourg City to the merged Council secretariat located in the Ravenstein building in Brussels.
In 1971, the Council and its secretariat relocated to the Charlemagne building, adjacent to the Commission's Berlaymont building.
The Council moved into the Justus Lipsius building in 1995, located across the road from Charlemagne.
After the move to Justus Lipsius, the Council continued to rent the Frère Orban building to house the Finnish and Swedish language divisions.
Since acquiring the Lex building in 2008, the Council services discontinued the use of the Kortenberg, Froissart, Espace Rolin, and Woluwe Heights buildings.

segmentAnalyses.segment: When the council is meeting in Luxembourg City, it meets in the Kirchberg Conference Centre,[65] and its offices are based at the European Centre on the plateau du Kirchberg.[49] The council has also met occasionally in Strasbourg, in various other cities, and also outside the Union: for example in 1974 when it met in Tokyo and Washington, D. C. while trade and energy talks were taking place. Under the council's present rules of procedures the council can, in extraordinary circumstances, hold one of its meetings outside Brussels and Luxembourg.[65]From 2017, both the Council of the European Union and the European Council adopted the purpose-built Europa building as their official headquarters, although they continue to utilise the facilities afforded by the adjacent Justus Lipsius building. The focal point of the new building, the distinctive multi-storey "lantern" shaped structure in which the main meeting room is located, is utilised in both EU institutions' new official logos.
segmentAnalyses.summary: When the Council meets in Luxembourg City, it utilizes the Kirchberg Conference Centre for meetings and bases its offices at the European Centre on the plateau du Kirchberg. While the Council can occasionally meet in other cities or outside the Union under extraordinary circumstances, both the Council of the European Union and the European Council adopted the purpose-built Europa building as their official headquarters starting in 2017, although they continue to use the adjacent Justus Lipsius building.
standaloneFacts: When the council meets in Luxembourg City, it meets in the Kirchberg Conference Centre.
The council's offices in Luxembourg City are based at the European Centre on the plateau du Kirchberg.
The council has met outside the Union, including in Tokyo and Washington, D. C. in 1974.
Under the council's present rules of procedures, the council can hold meetings outside Brussels and Luxembourg in extraordinary circumstances.
From 2017, the Council of the European Union and the European Council adopted the purpose-built Europa building as their official headquarters.
The Council of the European Union and the European Council continue to utilize the facilities of the adjacent Justus Lipsius building.
The Europa building features a distinctive multi-storey "lantern" shaped structure where the main meeting room is located.
The "lantern" shaped structure of the Europa building is utilized in both the Council of the European Union and the European Council's new official logos.
